data-innereditablearea="cell3"><p style="line-height: 22px;"><strong><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 24px;">APA ITEMS OF INTEREST</font></strong></p><p><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">The APA Council of Representatives (COR) will meet during the upcoming APA Convention in Chicago. Your AP-LS representatives are Tom Grisso and Jason Cantone. Of the more than 36 topics COR will discuss during the meeting, the below nine are likely of most interest to AP-LS members. If you have any comments about these items, please contact Jason Cantone, at <a href="mailto:jasoncantone@gmail.com">jasoncantone@gmail.com</a>, before August 6. We hope to see you at APA!</font></p><p>For the list of nine topics, please click <a href="https://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/resources/EmailTemplates/2019_08%20August%20AP-LS%20Newsletter/APAItemsOfInterest_0819.pdf" target="_blank">here</a>.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p style="line-height: 22px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 24px;"><strong>EXPERT OPINION: UPCOMING THREE PART SERIES</strong></font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">Best practices tell us to choose empirically supported treatment for the individual client. Though we have successfully developed such treatments for many forensic populations, there remains a lack of clearly identified and supported evidenced-based practices for individuals who have committed sexual offenses. In this three-part series, Amanda M. Fanniff, Ph.D., Associate Professor at Palo Alto University, will review current practices and examine whether such treatments actually “work.” This month’s column, Does Treatment for Adults who have Committed Sexual Offenses Work? A Simple Question with a Complicated Answer, focuses on adults who have committed sexual offenses and the next two will look at adolescents who have committed sexual offenses as well as minor attracted persons who want to remain offense-free. We start by asking the question, “How do we measure treatment in this area?”.&nbsp;</font></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">To read this column, please click <a href="https://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/resources/EmailTemplates/2019_08%20August%20AP-LS%20Newsletter/ExpertOpinion8_19.pdf" target="_blank">here</a>.&nbsp;</font></p><p><font style="font-size: 16px;"><br></font></p><div>  <div style="line-height: 18px;">    <div style="line-height: 18px;"></div>  </div></div></div></td>													</tr>												</tbody></table>											</td>										</tr>									</tbody></table>								</td><td width="200" align="" class="cellContainer cell4Container" valign="top">									<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">										<tbody><tr>											<td class="cellOuter" valign="top" style="padding: 0px;" data-cellouter="cell4">												<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-cellborder="1">													<tbody><tr>														<td class="cellInner" valign="top" style="background-position: 0% 0%; padding: 14px 8px 0px; background-image: none; background-repeat: repeat;" data-cellinner="cell4"><div id="idEditableArea_1480696629541_cell4" data-innereditablearea="cell4"><p style="line-height: 22px;"><strong><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif" style="font-size: 24px;">AP-LS BOOK AWARD COMMITTEE INVITES NOMINATIONS</font></strong></p><p style="line-height: 18px;"><font face="Trebuchet MS,sans-serif">The AP-LS Book Award Committee invites nominations to recognize outstanding scholarship in psychology and law edited books published in 2017 and 2018. The deadline for nominations is November 8, 2019.&nbsp; Nominations (including self-nominations) and e-versions of the book should be sent to the Chair of the Committee:&nbsp; Marie Comiskey, BA LLB LLM SJD, <a href="mailto:Marie.Comiskey@utoronto.ca">Marie.Comiskey@utoronto.ca</a>. The award will be presented at the upcoming AP-LS Conference in Portland in March 2020.
